thread.title: Briggs, get off that Louis Quinze table! Partying in Malcolm's new epoch
thread.title_full: Briggs, get off that Louis Quinze table! Partying in Malcolm's new epoch

title: Briggs, get off that Louis Quinze table! Partying in Malcolm's new epoch
text:
SKETCH
Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Video will begin in 5 seconds.
Don't play Play now More video Recommended Malcolm Turnbull's bookcase revealed
Terry Bailey: 'We just heard loud noises'
'Congested' level crossings not on Labor's removal list
Cool cop breaks up battle rap
Melbourne's worst level crossings overlooked
Replay video Return to video Video settings Please Log in to update your video settings
Katter cracks up the house Could any other MP be so cavalier as to ask a question and walk out halfway through the answer?
PT1M53S 620 349 Experts weigh in on Tony Abbott's smashed table Tony Abbott to pay for smashed marble table Scene: Prime Minister's office. Occasion: The New Epoch party. Attendance: PM, frontbench, assorted staff. Time: Midnight.
PM: Collaborators, allies, confreres. Compatriots all. I bid you God speed on our shared enterprise. Salutations! Onwards to destiny!
Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull: "God speed on our shared enterprise. Salutations!" Photo: Andrew Meares
Barnaby Joyce: What's he talking about?
Advertisement Julie Bishop (whispering): He doesn't want to mention Team Australia. He's slipped into his Roman period.
Barnaby: Hey, Malcolm, you got something cold and wet around here? I'm dry as a dead dingo's….
Hello Barnaby. Photo: Andrew Meares
PM: Barnabus. How good of you to join us. Big day plotting against poor dear Warren? Red? Dry white? Sparkling perhaps? The Veuve's nicely chilled.
Christopher Pyne: I spied a fruity little number lurking back there. One of those, thanks. Two, actually.
Barnaby: I just want a beer!
PM: Little, umm, unimaginative, Barnabus. Exciting new era, all that ...
Peter Dutton: Tony had slabs of the stuff!
PM: Mention that name in here again, Dutton, and you'll be drinking hemlock. On Nauru. Good God! Briggs, get down off that table! It's a Louis Quinze original!
Jamie Briggs: Whoops. Sorry, Malcolm. Seems to have collapsed a bit. Oooowwww. Bloody splinters up me ….
The Butler: Beg your pardon, your excellency. There's a person at the door, demanding entry.
PM: What? Who? Ahhh, Bronwyn, welcome to my humble soiree.
Bronwyn Bishop: Thank you, Malcolm. My invitation seems to have been misplaced..
PM: Oh, dear, I'm sure it was delivered. A canape? Devil on horseback?
Bronwyn: Get me a whisky sour and a pickled onion. Ohhh, Malcolm, I see you've got a statue of David installed. Big, isn't he?
PM: An early version by Michelangelo. Flawless, of course. Lay in the depths of a flooded quarry outside Firenze from 1498 till I arranged its rescue in 2013. Nicely offsets those lesser Elgin marbles I picked up during a Thucydides lecture tour in Athens. Please Bronwyn, don't hang your coat ...
Bronwyn: Oh, dear. Poor David. Chipped a little bit off his little bit. Not so flawless now. Wouldn't want any more of that, would we? If you were to whisper generously, say, about that nice position in Rome, I might be able to replace it.
PM: Hmmm. Bloody hell! Brandis! Fifield! Get away from those marbles.
Mitch Fifield: He started it. Just 'cos I got the arts and he didn't. Nyah nyah, poor old Bookshelf George.
George Brandis (crash-tackles Fifield): Upstart. Philistine. (The lesser Elgin marbles topple, shattering into numerous pieces).
Silence descends, followed a rush towards the drinks table. Bottles of Grange, most from the great year of 1990, with a sprinkling of Max Schubert's rare 1951 experimental vintage - go flying. The carpet is drenched, assuming a deep, complex hue, imparting a scent suggestive of leather, prunes, tobacco, cedar, coffee and aged detestations.
Barnaby: Bloody ripper party, this, Malcolm.
Jamie Briggs (his shirt discarded, a splinter crafted in the year 1743 by artisans living in the village bordering the Palace of Versailles protruding from his thigh): This is better than the old days, Malcolm. A few of us could begin to like you, y'know. Could you order me a wheelchair? I'll tell the journos I got gored by a bull on the way to question time.
PM: But what will I tell the cleaners?
Pyne: Just lock 'em out. Worked for Tony and Peta, begging your pardon. I know! Let's have a toga party next time.
